BOOKS and BOMBS

(ED. NOTE)
Those faculty members and students who looked over the bulletin
boards upon their return to Hopkins last week may have noticed an announcement to the effect that a collection of books, to be displayed in a
special alcove, would be formally presented to the University by the Italian
Government, through its consul, on Sunday, October 6. Those who visited
the Main Library no doubt observed the rows of books, in cardboard covers
of high visibility, awaiting the ceremony which was to make them iart of
the Italian Alcove.
This event at Hopkins, coinciding almost exactly with the bombing of
Aduwa, could hardly have been timed to take on greater significance.
Fascist Suppression
Thirteen years of Fascist dictatorship, maintained by repeated acts of
violence, the destruction of civil liberties, the persecution of intellectuals,
and the militarization of youth, have rightly brought the Italian Government into disrepute. The growing seriousness of Italy's economic situation;
increasing unemployment, repeated wage cuts, intensified poverty among
the masses, the intolerable pressure of taxation, the mounting public debt,
the decline of the lira—in short, the general "progress toward bankruptcy"
—has finally reached such a point that the government sees no way out
other than a barbarous war of annexation. Attempting to preserve itself
against its own inherent weaknesses, even at the cost of world conflict,
that government now embarks upon a mad career of invasion and slaughter.
A fitting moment indeed for that state to assume the ingratiating role
of donor to a famous university, and at the same time to secure a permanent advertisement foi- Italian Fascism!
Resentment Aroused
The sentiment which has already been aroused at Hopkins is far different from what the donor must have anticipated. Members of the faculty
.11111111111111111111111.111110MO
and of the student body, learning of the conditions upon which the gift was
NORMAN THOMAS
presented, have expressed their strong disapproval. Unfortunately, the ar—Courtesy News-Post
rangements preliminary to formal acceptance were evidently made at a time
when there were very few persons at the University to know that such action was under way.
The Hopkins Chapter of the American League Against War and Fascism
vigorously protests against the public acceptance of the gift and the setting
up of a special alcove for its display. The reasons for this protest will be
clear to anyone who considers the following questions:
Why does the Italian Government proffer gifts to American universities, when its own universities are relatively deserted and the standard of
Embargo On Warring, Pros- living of students in the dormitories has distinctly fallen?
Why does that government insist upon, and through its consul, pay for
pective Belligerent Nations a prominent display of the books it presents?

Students, who ordered but did
not receive their Hullabaloo last
year, may obtain them next week
at the Hullabaloo office, in Levering Hall, at 12:30.
All candidates for the editorial,
photographic and business staffs

open, and any man is eligible for
election.
Clarence Weimer is editor-inchief of the Hullabaloo, and Robert Levy, the business manager.

An infraction of the Rushing
Agreement by the Beta Theta Pi
fraternity was the main subject of
discussion at a meeting of the Interfraternity Board held last Tuesday.
The accusation against the Beta
Theta Pi fraternity was brought up
by several fraternities who charged
the organization with a "definite and
unethical violation of the regulations
of the Board." The infraction consisted of the Beta Theta Pi fraternity's
inviting freshmen out on Sunday, October 7, to a club and howling with
them, after having been previously
warned against such activities. The
Rushing Agreement stated that such
procedure was not to be allowed.

On The Interfrat Board - It is nothing more than the inevitable

From the University of Maryland comes news that
a new specie of white bed-bug has been discovered in
the temporary quarters of the girls who are awaiting
completion of the new dormitory. These bugs which
also infested the bathrooms—an action hitherto unheard
of in bugs of a related specie—kept the girls from going
to the bathroom to bathe for days at a stretch, until the
bathrooms finally started coming to the girls.

This Week's Aviation Story Of Ensign A. W. Dunning, I
Related By G. G. Duce, President Of The
Hopkins Aero Club
Ensign A. W. Dunning is attached
to the Aircraft Carrier U. S. S. Saratoga in Squadron VF-1, the "High
Hat" squadron, famous for its acrobatics. This squadron was filmed in
the motion picture "Hell-Divers",
featuring Wallace Beery.
While attached to the Saratoga,
Ensign Dunning figured in a rescue
that made naval history. During fleet
exercises off the west coast of Mexico, he was forced to land at sea when
his motor suddenly went dead. He
was one hundred miles from land and
there were no ships in sight. The
impact of the landing rendered nim
unconscious.
"It was like smashing into the side
of a mountain," Dunning says. "Just
how long I was unconscious is hard
to tell. The next thing I recall was
finding myself upside down, well under water, and still lashed tightly
and braced in the cockpit. I fumbled for my safety belt and unhooked
it and finally got on top. The plane
was sinking rapidly.
"Hurriedly I took off all of my
gear except my life-jacket, and then
took a deep breath of air and dove
down to the cockpit again, found the
floatation toggle (which releases
compressed carbon dioxide into bags
carried into the wings) and pulled
it. A hissing, bubbling sound told me
the gear was working and I came up
for air once more. I planned to rest
a little and 'allow the plane to arise
on her bags before attempting to dive
down again in an effort to get out

my rubber boat and emergency gear.
But it never did rise. The rough sea
tore the bags away, and, as the plane
sank from under me, I scrambled
along the wing in time to catch one
of the bags and hang on.
"Airplanes that I had not seen before were buzzing around. I noticed
one fellow in a fighter staggering
about in a .brave effort to do something. Probably he was trying to get
out his life raft to drop to me, but
he couldn't quite make it. A bomber
pilot circled low to try his luck in
the dramatic rescue. First I thought
he was going to land beside me, then
1 saw one of the mechanics out on
the wing pulling off some of the
cowling; he was getting out his rubber boat to drop to me. Would he inflate it first, then heave it over?
"If he should, I thought my chance
of getting to it would be small, because the wind might blow it away.
Around again he came, this time
lower and slower; and when right
close by, he heaved it over. That
truly was a remarkable feat, one
which took skill and courage. That
raft dropped on the windward side,
which was decidedly to my advantage."
Dunning climbed aboard the raft
and later was picked up by a destroyer. For the first time in naval history a man had been rescued by
dropping a boat from an aircraft.
And it all occurred on a Friday,
which was the thirteenth of the
month.

Favors An Embargo

BOOKS and BOMBS

(ED. NOTE)
Those faculty members and students who looked over the bulletin
boards upon their return to Hopkins last week may have noticed an announcement to the effect that a collection of books, to be displayed in a
special alcove, would be formally presented to the University by the Italian
Government, through its consul, on Sunday, October 6. Those who visited
the Main Library no doubt observed the rows of books, in cardboard covers
of high visibility, awaiting the ceremony which was to make them iart of
the Italian Alcove.
This event at Hopkins, coinciding almost exactly with the bombing of
Aduwa, could hardly have been timed to take on greater significance.
Fascist Suppression
Thirteen years of Fascist dictatorship, maintained by repeated acts of
violence, the destruction of civil liberties, the persecution of intellectuals,
and the militarization of youth, have rightly brought the Italian Government into disrepute. The growing seriousness of Italy's economic situation;
increasing unemployment, repeated wage cuts, intensified poverty among
the masses, the intolerable pressure of taxation, the mounting public debt,
the decline of the lira—in short, the general "progress toward bankruptcy"
—has finally reached such a point that the government sees no way out
other than a barbarous war of annexation. Attempting to preserve itself
against its own inherent weaknesses, even at the cost of world conflict,
that government now embarks upon a mad career of invasion and slaughter.
A fitting moment indeed for that state to assume the ingratiating role
of donor to a famous university, and at the same time to secure a permanent advertisement foi- Italian Fascism!
Resentment Aroused
The sentiment which has already been aroused at Hopkins is far different from what the donor must have anticipated. Members of the faculty
.11111111111111111111111.111110MO
and of the student body, learning of the conditions upon which the gift was
NORMAN THOMAS
presented, have expressed their strong disapproval. Unfortunately, the ar—Courtesy News-Post
rangements preliminary to formal acceptance were evidently made at a time
when there were very few persons at the University to know that such action was under way.
The Hopkins Chapter of the American League Against War and Fascism
vigorously protests against the public acceptance of the gift and the setting
up of a special alcove for its display. The reasons for this protest will be
clear to anyone who considers the following questions:
Why does the Italian Government proffer gifts to American universities, when its own universities are relatively deserted and the standard of
Embargo On Warring, Pros- living of students in the dormitories has distinctly fallen?
Why does that government insist upon, and through its consul, pay for
pective Belligerent Nations a prominent display of the books it presents?

An infraction of the Rushing
Agreement by the Beta Theta Pi
fraternity was the main subject of
discussion at a meeting of the Interfraternity Board held last Tuesday.
The accusation against the Beta
Theta Pi fraternity was brought up
by several fraternities who charged
the organization with a "definite and
unethical violation of the regulations
of the Board." The infraction consisted of the Beta Theta Pi fraternity's
inviting freshmen out on Sunday, October 7, to a club and howling with
them, after having been previously
warned against such activities. The
Rushing Agreement stated that such
procedure was not to be allowed.

On The Interfrat Board - It is nothing more than the inevitable

From the University of Maryland comes news that
a new specie of white bed-bug has been discovered in
the temporary quarters of the girls who are awaiting
completion of the new dormitory. These bugs which
also infested the bathrooms—an action hitherto unheard
of in bugs of a related specie—kept the girls from going
to the bathroom to bathe for days at a stretch, until the
bathrooms finally started coming to the girls.

familiarity with conditions at Maryland, this quotation

This Week's Aviation Story Of Ensign A. W. Dunning, I
Related By G. G. Duce, President Of The
Hopkins Aero Club
Ensign A. W. Dunning is attached
to the Aircraft Carrier U. S. S. Saratoga in Squadron VF-1, the "High
Hat" squadron, famous for its acrobatics. This squadron was filmed in
the motion picture "Hell-Divers",
featuring Wallace Beery.
While attached to the Saratoga,
Ensign Dunning figured in a rescue
that made naval history. During fleet
exercises off the west coast of Mexico, he was forced to land at sea when
his motor suddenly went dead. He
was one hundred miles from land and
there were no ships in sight. The
impact of the landing rendered nim
unconscious.
"It was like smashing into the side
of a mountain," Dunning says. "Just
how long I was unconscious is hard
to tell. The next thing I recall was
finding myself upside down, well under water, and still lashed tightly
and braced in the cockpit. I fumbled for my safety belt and unhooked
it and finally got on top. The plane
was sinking rapidly.
"Hurriedly I took off all of my
gear except my life-jacket, and then
took a deep breath of air and dove
down to the cockpit again, found the
floatation toggle (which releases
compressed carbon dioxide into bags
carried into the wings) and pulled
it. A hissing, bubbling sound told me
the gear was working and I came up
for air once more. I planned to rest
a little and 'allow the plane to arise
on her bags before attempting to dive
down again in an effort to get out

my rubber boat and emergency gear.
But it never did rise. The rough sea
tore the bags away, and, as the plane
sank from under me, I scrambled
along the wing in time to catch one
of the bags and hang on.
"Airplanes that I had not seen before were buzzing around. I noticed
one fellow in a fighter staggering
about in a .brave effort to do something. Probably he was trying to get
out his life raft to drop to me, but
he couldn't quite make it. A bomber
pilot circled low to try his luck in
the dramatic rescue. First I thought
he was going to land beside me, then
1 saw one of the mechanics out on
the wing pulling off some of the
cowling; he was getting out his rubber boat to drop to me. Would he inflate it first, then heave it over?
"If he should, I thought my chance
of getting to it would be small, because the wind might blow it away.
Around again he came, this time
lower and slower; and when right
close by, he heaved it over. That
truly was a remarkable feat, one
which took skill and courage. That
raft dropped on the windward side,
which was decidedly to my advantage."
Dunning climbed aboard the raft
and later was picked up by a destroyer. For the first time in naval history a man had been rescued by
dropping a boat from an aircraft.
And it all occurred on a Friday,
which was the thirteenth of the
month.
